thread.title_full: Job cuts stay on the agenda at WorleyParsons after $39m loss

title: Job cuts stay on the agenda at WorleyParsons after $39m loss
text:
WorleyParsons CEO Andrew Wood says the company will keep adapting to changing market conditions Photo: Jessica Hromas
﻿ WorleyParsons chief executive Andrew Wood says the engineering group is now one of the most "agile" companies in its sector after an extensive restructuring but has not ruled out further job cuts after reporting a $39 million annual loss.
"We will continually adjust to the amount of activity in the market to ensure we have a long term sustainable business," Mr Wood said after WorleyParsons revealed it had slashed its workforce by by 4200 people in the past 12 months and closed nine offices.
WorleyParsons warned in May that it would get rid of some 2000 jobs in the second half of the year, but cut more jobs than expected to save money. The group has reduced its global workforce by 8400 people over the past two years as demand for its engineering services has waned.
WorleyParsons CEO Andrew Wood says conditions in minerals and metals remain 'depressed'. Photo: Darrian Traynor
A smaller workforce allowed the company to respond to changing market conditions more quickly, Mr Wood said. "If the oil price falls further, or stays lower for longer, we do expect activity levels to fall."
Advertisement Statutory net profits were hurt by a $198.6 million write-down on goodwill after WorleyParsons lowered the carrying values of some assets, as well as booking charges for redundancy costs, office closures and the settlement of a dispute with ExxonMobil over an offshore drilling platform designed in Russia.
﻿ But WorleyParsons' shares, which have been trading at 10-year lows, rose 48¢, or 6.3 per cent, to $8.13 after revenues in the group's core hydrocarbons business fell only 1 per cent despite large spending cuts from its oil and gas customers.
Analysts said the company, which has been restructured over the past 18 months, appeared to be in a better position to handle the resources slump than it was a year ago.
WorleyParsons' new Advisian consultancy business, which contributed earnings of $14.1 million, was performing well and now employed 3000 people, Mr Wood said. "I see no reason why it can't get somewhere near the same size as the rest of the business."
Still, investors remain concerned about the outlook for future earnings.
WorleyParsons did not give any financial forecasts for 2016 and underlying profits, which exclude the goodwill impairment and charges, fell 25 per cent to $198.6 million.
WorleyParsons also halved its final dividend. It will pay a 22¢ final dividend, down from a 51¢ payout last year.
Earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) dropped in all of WorleyParsons' core businesses, with hydrocarbons down 8 per cent at $475 million; minerals metals and chemicals falling 59 per cent to $44 million; and infrastructure falling 56 per cent to $39 million.
The sudden cancellation of Canada's Kami iron ore project last year was the key cause of the sharp fall in income in minerals and metals division because WorleyParsons was given no warning, Mr Wood said.
Profit margins slid in all three divisions, with hydrocarbons margins running at 8.9 per cent compared with 9.6 per cent a year earlier; minerals, metals and chemicals margins at 4.9 per cent compared with 10.1 per cent a year earlier; and infrastructure margins at 1.7 per cent compared with 4.2 per cent a year earlier.
